author: David Sharos
title: Naperville protesters march to bring back censured Halloween 'spook house' Naperville Sun
text:
Sara Marston and a bunch of her friends had what Sara's mother, Heidi, called "a teachable moment" Saturday morning in a Naperville neighborhood.
As a sort of postscript, for now at least, for an event that has captured the interest of people around the world, the 11-year-old and about a dozen other kids and parents marched in a light rain for about four blocks to the home of Nick Thomas, whose annual Halloween decorations have become famous.
Chanting, "Bring back the spook house!" and boasting a myriad of placards, Sara and her charges arrived just before 9:30 a.m. at Thomas' house and met the man who has enchanted thousands with the more than 2,000 pieces of Halloween decorations he has put up for years until the local homeowner's association voted to put a limit on how many holiday decorations can be put on a property and how long they could stay up.
"It would have been wonderful if the president and some of the people from the homeowner's association had shown up today and said, 'Let's just forget about this right now – we know you need this and know what it's meant to people,' but that's not going to happen," Thomas said as he waited for Sara and her group to arrive. "Maybe I'll still do my Christmas decorations – we'll have to see."
As Heidi Marston began to unload her van Saturday morning, which was filled with signs and a number of kids, she spoke about the bold actions of her daughter and said that for her, "the heat of the issue is that this is a teachable moment."
"Both sides in this issue have a point as well as various solutions, but this has given Sara a lot of confidence," Heidi said about her daughter. "She joked about maybe having a future career after this in politics or something. The thing that really got her going was the signatures she got from around the world on her (online) petition. Every time the total went up another 100 – that seemed to be a benchmark."
The Halloween display at a home in south Naperville has attracted national attention for the dozens of ghosts, goblins and skeletons in the front yard and its dazzling light show set to music.
To date, Sara has garnered more than 10,000 signatures from around the world supporting her measure to bring back the haunted house on Conan Doyle Road, though relatively few signatures came from Illinois. Thomas' next-door neighbor Jim Jandick, who represented Thomas at a homeowner's association meeting where the issue was discussed, said there is a bigger back story to the whole issue that needs to see the light of day.
"When Nick started playing the Queen song 'Bohemian Rhapsody' last year and even the band was talking about it, everybody did what I call 'a face plant' on Facebook – that's what I call it – after the thing went viral," Jandick said. "But what really matters is a couple of days before Halloween last year, a bus from (Naperville School) District 203 came over with all these high school kids and each one was a caregiver for someone in a wheelchair. Having a haunted house made their day."
Fellow marcher Matthias Berck said he has lived in Naperville the past two years and called what young Sara has done "remarkable."

(Jane Donahue) "I can see both sides of this issue as far as the homeowners' association and what people living here want to do, but the fact Sara has pulled this off is remarkable," Berck said. "People have enjoyed coming here, both for Halloween and Christmas, and folks really like the 'show' it seems."
Bobby Stevens, who lives in Lockport, has friends in the neighborhood and decided she needed to come out and support the cause.
"I protest against the fact that a few people's decision has affected the whole subdivision," she said. "I think it's amazing how support has picked up. I don't feel there should be any restrictions and this could really be a show if it wasn't for some Ebenezer Scrooges. There has been so much enjoyment, especially for the handicapped kids that have visited and the ones that live here."
After shaking hands with Thomas and offering him a copy of the petition signatures, Sara offered another solution to the problem.
"Maybe you could put half the decorations on your lawn, and the other half on the next door neighbor's, and then we'd have it all," she said in reference to the homeowner's decision about how much of the property decorations could occupy.
"There you go," Jandick replied. "That would be fine with me."
David Sharos is a freelance reporter for the Naperville Sun.
